conclusion: Consider effects of gravity, collision, and deflection to determine collision and landing position of block A.
Block A is initially above the table.
Block A will fall straight down due to gravity.
Yellow blocks are directly below A's initial path.
Block A will collide with the yellow blocks first when it falls.
A may be deflected upon hitting the yellow blocks depending on the elasticity of the collision.
If the collision is inelastic, A might come to rest on top of the yellow blocks.
If the collision is elastic, A could bounce off the yellow blocks.
Direction of deflection depends on the angle and force of the collision.
If A bounces, it could move towards adjacent blocks (orange or blue) depending on the direction of deflection.
Green and blue blocks are further away from A's initial path.
A is less likely to reach green and blue blocks unless deflected strongly.
Most likely, A will either rest on the yellow blocks or bounce slightly but remain near them due to proximity and direct path of the fall.
Block A will collide with the yellow blocks and likely come to rest on or very near them.
It is unlikely for A to reach the orange or blue blocks unless deflected significantly.
